Table 1 Catalyst type Examples Potential active sites Confirmed advantages Reference Basic Li2CO3, Na2CO3, and K2CO3 Cations and anions in solution Liquid products have diesel-like chemical composition with low acid values and poor cold-flow properties. [21,22] Metal oxide MgO, TiO2, and CaO Unsaturated coordination and defect sites Catalysts exhibit decent performance upon heteroatom removal. [23–25] Zeolite H-ZSM-5 (microporous),MCM-41 (mesoporous),Y-zeolite/MCM-41 (micro/mesoporous) Brønsted and Lewis acid centres produced via isomorphous substitution Catalysts have high acidity, thermal stability, and excellent selectivity for gasoline production.High selectivity towards aromatic hydrocarbons;Catalysts with mesopores can increase carbon chain length. [26–29] Silica–alumina SiO2/Al2O3 Unsaturated coordination and defect sites Low-cost catalysts used in early research on catalytic pyrolysis. [30] Composite CaO/Al2O3,Cu-ZSM-5, andAg2O3-La2O3/activated carbon Similar to those in zeolites and metal oxides Composite catalysts exhibit decent performance in terms of all their active components, and the synthesis strategy can be optimised depending on the desired liquid fuel requirements (gasoline, kerosene, or diesel). [11,17,25,31,32] Others SiC, activated carbon, W2C, multiwalled carbon nanotubes, and PbOPO4 Heteroatom doping or defects in carbon materials, and others Decent performance in unique aspects such as deoxygenation, aromatisation, and carbon chain cracking; disadvantageous in terms of comprehensive and large-scale application. Xiping Road No. 5340, Beichen District Tianjin 300401 PR China Non-edible lipids are an alternative source of liquid hydrocarbon fuels, particularly aviation fuels. As a transformation pathway, the catalytic pyrolysis of lipids can remove oxygen atoms and modify molecular structures via carbon chain cracking and aromatisation. However, this pathway has not yet been certified for the production of alternative aviation fuels. Therefore, a detailed review of various heterogeneous catalysts for the conversion of lipids into hydrocarbon fuels with molecular weights and structures suitable for use in aviation is presented herein, with a focus on aspects such as their physical and chemical properties, pore distributions and structures, active sites, key functions, catalytic performance, and pyrolysis mechanisms. Metal oxides can effectively remove oxygen atoms, whereas zeolites can achieve long-carbon-chain cracking to yield desirable gasoline-, kerosene-, or diesel-range fuels. Moreover, zeolites typically permit aromatisation, which yields the aromatic hydrocarbons required for liquid fuels. Modification of the pore structures of zeolites to yield hierarchical pores can improve the production of C8–C16-range liquid fuels to maximise the bio-kerosene yield. Therefore, composite catalysts (metal oxides supported on zeolites with hierarchical pores) can be effective for molecular-level structural modification in the pyrolytic production of alternative aviation fuels using lipids. However, rapid deactivation due to coking, poisoning, and sintering hinder the operation of these catalysts. Coking, which is predominantly responsible for pyrolysis catalyst deactivation, should be targeted in future research on novel catalysts. The synthetic strategy of catalysts and the mitigation of their issues are critical to the design of novel catalytic pyrolysis systems for the efficient cracking of triglyceride-rich feedstock to yield alternative aviation fuels. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Non-edible lipids Catalytic pyrolysis Liquid hydrocarbons Composite catalysts Alternative aviation fuels Microalgae 1 Introduction The realisation of sustainable development and the accelerating consumption of liquid fuels necessitate the production of alternative liquid fuels from non-edible lipids sourced from biomass, such as Jatropha curcas, Ricinus communis, microalgae, and waste cooking oil. The lipids in these feedstocks typically contain triglycerides, which have a glycerol group and three long-chain saturated/unsaturated fatty acids, whose structure is similar to that of the liquid hydrocarbons in petroleum-based gasoline, kerosene, and diesel. The presence of long carbon chains in these lipids highlights their remarkable potential for the production of liquid hydrocarbon fuels. Lipids can be converted into liquid biofuels through several pathways, including microbial fermentation, transesterification, gasification-integrated Fischer–Tropsch synthesis, hydrotreatment, catalytic pyrolysis, and hydrothermal liquification. For example, lipids can be converted into bioethanol via microbial fermentation within several days, and the produced bioethanol is blended with conventional gasoline at a maximum content of 20% [1]. However, it has low mass and energy efficiencies because of the production of a large amount of fermentation residue and the use of sugar and lignocellulosic biomass as feedstock instead of lipids. Oxygen-containing biodiesel can be produced via transesterification, which is a reaction conducted between lipids and alcohols using acid or base catalysts to form esters and a glycerol by-product [2]. Biodiesel and bioethanol show tremendous potential for application in internal combustion engines for on-road transportation; however, they are unsuitable for aviation engines. Gasification-integrated Fischer–Tropsch synthesis can technically produce high-performance liquid fuels [3]; however, it has a high energy consumption and a complex reaction process involving conversion of the feedstocks into CO and H2, followed by additional molecular-level combinations. Hydrotreatment can remove oxygen atoms using catalysts at reaction temperatures of 250–350 °C and H2 reaction pressures of 2–10 MPa following a strict operational procedure, indicating a large consumption of H2 (200–300 m3/m3-lipid) [4]. However, catalytic pyrolysis can convert lipids into liquid hydrocarbon fuels in an inert hydrogen-free environment under mild reaction conditions (atmospheric pressure and 300–600 °C) [5]. A comparison of the aforementioned reaction pathways suggests that catalytic pyrolysis is particularly conducive to the production of liquid hydrocarbon fuels from non-edible lipids, owing to advantages such as catalytic removal of carboxyl groups and lack of hydrogen consumption, thereby permitting sustainable replacement of petroleum-based liquid fuels. A brief comparison of the pathways for alternative-aviation-fuel production is presented in Section 2.2. Pyrolysis is an age-old technique that can be categorised into thermal (non-catalytic) and catalytic processes [6,7]. Non-catalytic pyrolysis of lipids is conducted in an oxygen-free environment at temperatures of 300–600 °C, yielding renewable products including bio-oil, combustible gas, and bio-char, instead of petroleum-based products. High yields of bio-oil are obtained via pyrolysis typically at high heating rates, whereas biochar or activated carbon are generally produced via slow pyrolysis [8]. Although fast pyrolysis requires medium temperatures and atmospheric pressure, the produced bio-oil primarily comprises oxygen-containing and acidic compounds (such as alcohols, aldehydes, ketones, fatty acids, and esters), along with a low hydrocarbon content ( Fig. 1). However, bio-oil is not suitable for internal combustion and aviation engines because of its high oxygen content, poor stability, and high acid value [9,10]. Therefore, catalytic pyrolysis was developed to overcome the drawbacks of bio-oil obtained via non-catalytic pyrolysis and achieve high-value utilisation of the pyrolysis products. Catalytic pyrolysis has been employed to improve the quality of the produced bio-oil, and has already been applied in the petroleum industry for many years, for instance, in fluidised-bed catalytic cracking of heavy fuel oil into gasoline and olefins [12]. Typical heterogeneous catalysts used in the pyrolysis of lipids, including metal oxides [13], zeolites [14], silica–alumina materials [15], carbides [16], nitrides, and composite catalysts [17], are listed in Table 1, along with their active sites and catalytic performance. These catalysts operate primarily by removing heteroatoms (mainly oxygen atom), ensuring suitable cracking and isomerisation of long carbon chains, and enabling aromatisation of the molecular structures in the lipids. These functions can be achieved by the unique active sites and pore structures of the catalysts. Therefore, the development of high-activity high-selectivity multifunctional catalysts is key to catalytic pyrolysis. Nano-scale, single-atom, and composite catalysts with hierarchical structures have recently been prepared using novel catalyst synthesis strategies for pyrolysis [18,19]. Additionally, the role of catalysts in pyrolysis should be comprehensively assessed in light of the recent changes in industrial feedstocks from petroleum or heavy oil to biomass-based feedstocks in recent years. New challenges should be addressed in this regard, such as the effects of biomass-based feedstocks, i.e. feedstocks with higher oxygen (>10%) and nitrogen contents (>2%) than those of petroleum and coal. Additionally, the global trend of adopting electrification instead of internal combustion engines for cars [20] must be acknowledged, in that catalysts with high selectivity must be designed for the production of aviation fuels instead of gasoline and diesel via the catalytic conversion of lipids. Therefore, this review presents a comprehensive summary of the catalytic pyrolysis of lipids to provide appropriate information for improving its aviation fuel yield and economy, with a focus on the functions and deactivation processes of catalysts. First, an overview of the lipid composition and alternative aviation fuel production is presented to provide the relevant research background, including a brief comparison of the main production pathways of alternative aviation fuels from a techno-economics viewpoint. Furthermore, all types of catalysts used in the catalytic pyrolysis of lipids are summarised in terms of the characteristics, performance, and pyrolysis mechanisms of the catalysts. The characteristics of the catalysts include physical and chemical properties, pore distribution and size, and identification of active sites. The catalytic performance and functions include the oxygen removal efficiency, degree of cracking, aromatisation, and isomerisation. In the discussion on catalytic mechanisms, the main reaction pathways and evolution of the molecular structure of lipids are explored with respect to their transformation into liquid hydrocarbon fuels, particularly alternative aviation fuels. Additionally, recent research on the use of microalgal lipids to produce alternative aviation fuels via catalytic pyrolysis is reviewed, considering the advantages of microalgae in terms of growth and lipid accumulation. Finally, suggestions for advancing research on catalytic pyrolysis are provided, with a focus on large-scale low-cost production of feedstocks, engineering of the active sites in catalysts, deactivation mechanisms of catalysts, improvement of economics, and certification of pathways for pyrolysis-based alternative-aviation-fuel production. This review provides a thorough outline of catalytic pyrolysis for the production of lipid-derived alternative aviation fuels, along with its industrial applications and commercial viability. 2 Overview of alternative aviation fuels 2.1 Composition of alternative aviation fuels Petroleum-based aviation fuels are important liquid hydrocarbon fuels that have contributed to the rapid development of the global aviation industry; however, they have resulted in increasing greenhouse gas emissions over the last few decades. Aviation-derived global CO2 emissions are predicted to reach 5% of global greenhouse gas emissions by 2050 owing to the continuing expansion of the global aviation sector [35]. Because conventional petroleum-based aviation fuels are predominantly used as the main engine fuels in the aviation industry, fuel expenditure is a significant proportion of the operational cost [36]. Aviation fuels are complex mixtures of hydrocarbons in the C8–C16 range, and include four compound families: linear alkanes, branched alkanes/iso-alkanes, cycloalkanes, and aromatic hydrocarbons [37]. Aviation fuel standards, such as ASTM D1655 (“Standard Specification for Aviation Turbine Fuels”), ASTM D7566 (“Standard Specification for Aviation Turbine Fuel Containing Synthesized Hydrocarbons”), and RP-3 (China), have established specific concentration limits for aromatic hydrocarbons (8–25%), olefins (<5%), and cycloalkanes (<15% for blending components), respectively. Although there are no specific guidelines for alkane and cycloalkane contents, a high iso-alkane/n-alkane ratio and a high cycloalkane content are beneficial for improving fuel density and mitigating emissions. A typical aviation fuel composition includes 28.1%, 38.8%, 1.2%, 15.1%, and 14.4% n-paraffins, iso-paraffins, olefins, naphthenes, and aromatics, respectively [38]. Strict production standards and requirements exist for the physical and chemical properties of aviation fuels to adhere to air safety protocols. The complicated relationships between the physical/chemical properties of aviation fuels and their combustion performance in airplane chambers are systematically illustrated in Fig. 2. Alternative aviation fuels have been actively researched and developed to reduce CO2 emissions from the aviation sector. Compared with the enhancements of airplane/aero-engine technology and flight route optimisation, the development of alternative aviation fuels shows greater potential for reducing aviation-related CO2 emissions. Alternative aviation fuels exhibit excellent environmental and combustion performance. For example, alternative aviation fuels exhibit superior thermal oxidative stability compared to that of JP-8 and increased resistance to carbon formation when used to cool aircraft systems [39]. The cetane number of alternative aviation fuels is higher than that of Jet-A because of the higher aromatic content in Jet-A (~20%) [40]. Neat alternative aviation fuels (gas-to-liquid fuels and fatty acid ethyl esters) have lower formaldehyde emissions than those of conventional petroleum-based fuels [41]. Additionally, liquid aviation fuels cannot be easily replaced by electricity or liquid H2/O2 over a short duration owing to the power requirement of engines and safe operation. Alternative aviation fuels are produced via pathways including gasification-integrated Fischer–Tropsch synthesis, hydro-processing of esters and fatty acids, alcohol-to-jet conversion, hydrothermal liquefaction, the sugar-to-hydrocarbon strategy, and catalytic pyrolysis. Triglyceride-based biomass, such as oil plants, microalgal lipids, and waste vegetable oil, is primarily used as a feedstock [36,37,42]. However, certain lipid characteristics hinder their direct utilisation as liquid fuels. For example, the presence of heteroatoms, mainly elemental oxygens, in lipids reduces the heat value and stability of the resulting aviation fuels. The length of the carbon chain, which is generally more than 16, is also worth considering because it establishes the balance between flammability under high-temperature conditions and frost resistance in low-temperature air. Additionally, 8–25% aromatic hydrocarbons are required in aviation fuels to ensure the lubrication of mechanical structures and permit elastomer swelling. Therefore, lipids must be converted into pure hydrocarbon fuels and be fully compatible with existing systems and engines, that is, to realise drop-in biofuels. Deoxygenation, molecular-level structural modification (carbon chain cracking and isomerisation), and aromatisation are critical steps that must be undertaken prior to the use of lipids in aviation biofuels [43]. Catalytic pyrolysis of lipids in a hydrogen-free environment using optimised catalysts can satisfy these requirements of alternative aviation fuels [5,44,45]. The catalytic pyrolysis of lipids differs remarkably from that of lignocellulosic biomass in terms of product distribution, operating conditions, and catalyst used [8,46,47]. In terms of the lipid composition, lignocellulosic biomass has a typical composition of cellulose, hemicellulose, and lignin, which have a high oxygen content (>40%). Fewer liquid products are generated via pyrolysis of lignocellulosic biomass than those of lipids because a considerable amount of biochar (30%) is produced from lignocellulosic biomass [48], whereas a miniscule coke content is produced by lipids (<5%). Moreover, the temperature for lignocellulosic biomass pyrolysis (>500 °C) is higher than that of lipids (300–450 °C). Although similar catalysts are employed in these scenarios (metal oxides, zeolites, and composite catalysts), they are utilised in different manners [49,50]. Catalysts are used in the pyrolysis of lignocellulosic biomass mostly in two forms: in situ (blending of biomass and catalyst) and ex situ (reaction between pyrolysis volatiles and catalysts), whereas heated feedstock is directly reacted with catalysts during the catalytic pyrolysis of lipids. Therefore, if the feedstock price difference between lipids and lignocellulosic biomass is not considered, lipids are more suitable for catalyst-assisted pyrolytic production of alternative aviation fuels from the viewpoints of composition and operation. The functions of catalysts essential for alternative-aviation-fuel production via lipid pyrolysis in terms of the conversion pathways are shown in Fig. 3, along with the characteristics of lipids and specifications of alternative aviation fuels. Several studies have been conducted to improve the functions of these catalysts. For example, aviation fuel has been produced from palm-based biomass using several types of deoxygenation catalysts (CaO, zeolite, V2O5, Pd/C, and TiO2); the fuel primarily comprises n-paraffins, iso-paraffins, naphthenes, and aromatics, with 73% jet paraffin selectivity (C8–C16) [51]. Several plant oils (soybean and rubber seed oils) and waste triglycerides (waste cooking and acidified plant oils) have also been used to produce aviation range fuels with high yields (55–60%) in a two-step catalytic conversion, which realised carbon chain cracking, aromatisation, and hydrogenation in a one-pot catalyst synthesis [43]. NbOPO4 is known to be a high-performance catalyst, similar to zeolites and metal oxides, as it exhibits high selectivity to aviation fuel (58%), followed by diesel (37%) and gasoline (21%) [33]. Despite the numerous studies conducted on catalytic lipid pyrolysis, selective production of alternative aviation fuels from lipids has not been comprehensively achieved; moreover, the carbon number distribution of the produced liquid fuels is often unsuitable for aviation-related applications (especially for the C8–C16 kerosene range). Therefore, the catalysts used in the pyrolysis of lipids and their functions are comprehensively analysed in Section 3 to enable enhancements in the process of catalytic pyrolysis. 2.2 Economic analysis of alternative aviation fuels Prior to conducting a detailed review of various catalysts, the different conversion pathways from lipids to alternative aviation fuels must be compared to clarify the advantages and challenges involved in the catalytic pyrolysis of lipids. This will provide more information or perspectives on the functions of these catalysts and their optimisation for pyrolysis. As mentioned earlier, the main pathways for the production of alternative aviation fuels include gasification-integrated Fischer–Tropsch synthesis, hydrotreatment of esters and fatty acids, conversion of sugar/alcohols into bio-jet, hydrothermal liquification, and catalytic pyrolysis [52,53]. These pathways must realise considerably high oxygen removal efficiencies while adhering to the specifications of alternative aviation fuels because the total C and H content must be greater than 99% according to standards. The major differences between these pathways are likely related to product yield and economics. Hydrotreatment of lipids theoretically removes oxygen in the form of H2O without loss of carbon. For example, the use of a Ni/CeAl-3.0 catalyst for hydrotreatment of lipids afforded a 97.1% n-C17 yield with 99.9% methyl oleate conversion at 2.5 MPa H2 and 300 °C for 6 h [54]. Catalytic pyrolysis removes oxygen in the form of CO2, which slightly reduces its carbon efficiency. For example, a mesoporous SiO2–Al2O3 supported Co-Ca catalyst showed a high deoxygenation efficiency with a maximum hydrocarbon n-(C8–C20) yield of 73% and high selectivity for n-C15 and n-C17 fractions [55]. The gasification-integrated Fischer–Tropsch synthesis pathway consumes a significant amount of energy to convert feedstock into H2 and CO, and subsequently combine them into C8–C16 hydrocarbons; this can lead to a lower carbon efficiency if the energy is sourced from a portion of the feedstocks. Moreover, this pathway employs lignocellulosic biomass, municipal solid waste, or coal/tar as feedstocks. Therefore, the hydrotreatment pathway clearly has technical advantages in terms of product and carbon yields, which is corroborated by the fact that half of the test flight activities performed using alternative fuels have been conducted using hydro-processed esters and fatty acids. Economic feasibility is an important consideration in the utilisation of lipid-based aviation fuels. These fuels exhibit lower economic efficiencies than those of petroleum-based aviation fuels owing to feedstock cost and availability. Lipids are obtained via the extraction of biomass or microalgae rather than from waste material, except for waste cooking oil. Lipids have an apparent advantage in terms of liquid fuel yield compared to high-oxygen-content lignocellulosic feedstocks; however, they have a higher feedstock price than that of lignocellulosic biomass. The yield of alternative aviation fuels should be greater than 0.58 Mg-fuel/Mg-dry-feedstock to compete with petroleum-based aviation fuels [53]. Commercial-scale production of alternative aviation fuels from non-edible oils has been attempted by biorefinery companies such as UOP Honeywell and SkyNRG, which employ hydrodeoxygenation and isomerisation/selective cracking processes. Hydro-deoxygenation produces alternative aviation fuels by consuming large amounts of hydrogen (~300–420 m3 of H2/m3 for vegetable oil) [56]. In contrast, catalytic pyrolysis does not require hydrogen and removes oxygen via CO2 using the deoxygenation, cracking, isomerisation, and aromatisation processes, which slightly reduces its carbon efficiency and fuel yield compared to those of hydro-deoxygenation [33]. Theoretically, the catalytic pyrolysis of lipids provides economic advantages over commercial hydro-processing from the perspective of hydrogen consumption. The different catalytic pathways can also be compared in terms of ASTM-certified routes (gasification-integrated Fischer–Tropsch synthesis, hydro-processing of ester and fatty acids, and the alcohol-to-jet strategy) and catalytic pyrolysis. For example, renewable aviation fuel derived from the Fischer–Tropsch processing of rice husk feedstock at a plant capacity of 600 t/d has higher mass, energy, and carbon yields than those of catalytic pyrolysis. The minimum selling price (MSP) for the aviation fuel obtained via the Fischer–Tropsch synthesis ($2.20/L) was lower than that derived from catalytic pyrolysis ($3.21/L) [57]. Compared with the Fischer–Tropsch synthesis and alcohol-to-jet conversion, the hydro-processing of esters and fatty acids shows optimal performance in terms of the production cost and greenhouse gas emissions owing to its higher yield and lower capital cost (closer to full commercialisation) [58]. Catalytic hydro-thermolysis – an uncommon reaction pathway – can also transform lipids into alternative aviation fuels via complex integrated reactions, which involve major processes such as preconditioning, catalytic hydro-thermolysis conversion, and post-refining, as well as auxiliary processes. The MSPs of alternative aviation fuels obtained via catalytic hydrothermolysis from the feedstock of soybean oil, carinata oil, yellow grease, and brown grease were $1.50/L, $1.32/L, $1.19/L and $1.00/L, respectively [59]. Additionally, an economic analysis of pyrolysis bio-oil upgrading to alternative aviation fuels via hydro-processing, gasification-integrated Fischer–Tropsch synthesis, and zeolite cracking was conducted, and the MSPs of the resulting aviation fuels were determined to be $1.98/L, $2.32/L, and $2.21/L, respectively [60]. However, further research is required on the economic assessment of different catalytic pathways for alternative-aviation-fuel production with similar considerations (feedstock, scale, and location). Sensitivity analysis performed in related techno-economic research has indicated that the price of lipids, aviation fuel yield (carbon efficiency or kerosene selectivity), and plant scale are the main factors determining the MSP of aviation fuels, which, in turn, indicates the large-scale-commercialisation viability of different alternative aviation fuels. Low feedstock costs and large plants facilitate the cost-effective production and applications of alternative aviation fuels. Carbon efficiency is an index representing the transformation of feedstock into alternative fuels. The hydrotreatment of lipids has a higher carbon efficiency than that of catalytic pyrolysis because most of the oxygen is removed from these processes in the form of H2O and CO2, respectively; moreover, the aviation fuel yield from the latter is reduced. For example, flowsheet simulation of material and energy balance in the fluidised-bed catalytic cracking of algae oil, followed by hydrotreatment of intermediates, indicated an energy efficiency of 95% and aviation fuel yield of 41% [61]. Catalytic deoxygenation of palm oil over 8 wt% Pd/C at 400 °C for 2 h led to a jet paraffin selectivity (C8–C16) of 73%, and the physicochemical properties of resulting liquid fuels complied with those of standard Jet A-1 fuel in terms of ASTM standards [51]. However, the catalytic pyrolysis of lipids into alternative aviation fuels remains hindered by technical and economic challenges, which must be tackled to enable large-scale production and certification by governments or organisations. Numerous types of catalysts have been developed in the past few decades to improve the yield and selectivity for aviation fuels; these are thoroughly reviewed in Section 3. 3 Functions of catalysts during pyrolytic production of alternative aviation fuels Catalytic pyrolysis is an important pathway for the production of alternative aviation fuels with complex compositions, as mentioned in Section 2. Large-scale industrial production of alternative aviation fuels via the catalytic pyrolysis of non-edible lipids requires multifunctional catalysts. The specific functions of these catalysts include heteroatom removal (mainly oxygen atoms), carbon chain modification, and aromatisation of desirable products (Fig. 3) [62–64]. In this section, these functions are discussed from the perspectives of catalyst characterisation, catalytic performance, active sites, and the catalytic reaction mechanisms. 3.1 Catalysts for heteroatom removal Heterogeneous catalysts play a crucial role in the pyrolysis of non-edible lipids in terms of the removal of heteroatoms (mainly oxygen atoms) from the ester groups of lipids; this is primarily realised by metal oxides in the form of bulk catalysts or active components doped into various supports. Metals used for the deoxygenation include Na, K, Ca, Mg, Al, Ti, V, Fe, Nd, Cu, Mo, Co, Ce, Zr, and Ni [65–67]; these can be categorised into alkaline, alkaline earth, transition, noble (rarely used individually), and rare-earth metals ( Table 2). These metals are used as catalysts during pyrolysis in the form of their oxides rather than in their elemental forms or as alloys. Most metal oxides are used as active components with various types of supports, such as activated carbon, silica, and molecular sieves, to reduce catalyst costs or to improve catalytic activities. Section 3.1 discusses bulk catalysts (single metal oxides), whereas Section 4 presents information on metal oxide catalysts supported on various types of supports (that is, composite catalysts). Generally, metal oxides have low specific surface areas (<50 m2/g), pore diameters of 10–30 nm, and active sites that are mainly unsaturated coordination sites (such as edges, corners, terraces, kinks, and steps) and defect sites (such as vacancies, dislocations, interstitial atoms, stacking faults, twin boundaries, and grain boundaries) in their crystals [25]. Metal oxides exhibit decent oxygen-removal performance and yield catalytic pyrolysis products with primarily diesel-like components because of their weak carbon-chain-cracking ability [68,69]. For example, catalysts based on noble metals (Pd and Pt) are typically used in oxygen removal reactions and offer high removal efficiencies (>90%) [72]; however, these types of catalysts are extremely expensive and limited in terms of availability. In the catalytic pyrolysis of waste cooking oil, MnO x and TiO2 resulted in an overall decrease in the free-fatty-acid content, but differed in terms of preference for alkenes and alkanes, in that TiO2 and Mn(IV)O were slightly selective towards alkanes and alkenes, respectively [73]. MgO-supported catalysts produced liquid hydrocarbons with a carbon number of C10–C20, which were primarily a mixture of straight- and branched-chain hydrocarbons; moreover, the liquid products showed low acid value and iodine value (<5 mg-KOH/g and ~80 g-I/100 g, respectively) [74]. Metal oxide catalysts with more surface-oxygen species facilitate CO2 adsorption for decarboxylation primarily via the formation of metal oxide carbonates [75]. In conclusion, metal oxides can facilitate deoxygenation reactions and promote decarboxylation and decarbonylation reactions to produce hydrocarbons. Metal oxides, such as alkaline metals, alkaline-earth metals, transition metals, noble metals, and rare-earth metals, exhibit varying catalytic performances during pyrolysis. For example, catalysts with different amounts of MgO (30%, 63%, and 70%) decreased the oxygen content to less than 1% at 400 °C in the catalytic pyrolysis of a model compound (oleic acid) [76]. Vanadium oxide (V2O5) achieved a conversion rate of 87.6% at 320 °C in 40 min for commercial-grade sunflower oil. The physical characteristics (density, specific gravity, higher heat value, flash point, and kinematic viscosity) of the obtained product were in accordance with ASTM D6751 (B100) standards [77]. Zirconium oxide (ZrO2) enhanced the properties of waste cooking oil by catalytic pyrolysis, which enabled improvements in kinematic viscosity, density, and calorific value from 43.75 to 3.55 mm2/s, 0.96–0.86 g/cm3, and 38.9–40.8 MJ/kg, respectively [13]. The addition of tungsten oxide (WO x ) to Pt/TiO2 remarkably enhanced the deoxygenation efficiency up to 86% in the production of bio-jet-range alkanes, which was more than two times that of the Pt/TiO2 catalyst in the deoxygenation of non-edible acid oils without any added hydrogen [68]. The oxygen in the lipids was mostly removed by these catalysts via the decarboxylation (removal of CO2) and decarbonylation (removal of CO and H2O) pathways. Additionally, various rare-earth-based catalysts, such as CeO2 and La2O3, have been employed in pyrolysis, and have exhibited improved activity and hydrothermal stability to combat the effect of contaminants [78]. Research on the stabilisation mechanism of Y zeolite modified with different rare-earth ions has indicated that the multi-coordination model of the rare-earth ions was more important for the optimisation of hydrothermal stability than the number of rare-earth ions in the supports [79]. Although metal oxides have excellent oxygen removal characteristics, they have a weak ability to modify carbon chains and cannot transform lipids into alternative aviation fuels in one step. The main reaction mechanism for heteroatom removal during catalytic pyrolysis involves the decarbonylation and decarboxylation reactions that remove oxygen via the formation of CO and CO2. The proposed mechanism for the catalytic pyrolysis of triglycerides to produce hydrocarbons using metal oxide catalysts is shown in Fig. 4. First, metal oxides react with the fatty acids in lipids and yield fatty acid salts at low cracking temperatures. When the catalytic pyrolysis temperature increases, the carboxyl and carbonyl groups in the fatty acid salts undergo cracking, and metal oxides are released from the long carbon chain of the fatty acid salts [80]. Additionally, certain carbon-chain transformations (bond cleavage, disproportionation, hydrogen abstraction, isomerisation, and aromatisation) have also been observed as side reactions. In particular, free-radical and carbonium-ion mechanisms have helped elucidate the catalytic pyrolysis reaction [75]. At the molecular level, heavily oxygenated compounds such as carboxylic acids, esters, aldehydes, and ketones, which result from primary thermal cracking, undergo decarboxylation and decarbonylation via β-scission of C–C bonds and C–O cleavage to form low-carbon-number compounds [81]. Although metal oxides have decent oxygen-removal abilities, they can be deactivated during catalytic pyrolysis. For instance, CaO deactivation has been observed in the catalytic pyrolysis of waste cooking oil and free fatty acids. The presence of Ca(OH)2 and CaCO3 in the deactivated catalyst indicated that crystal phase and agglomeration considerably influenced catalyst stability [82]. Catalyst deactivation is described in detail in Section 5. Additionally, ketonisation and aldol condensation reactions also play key roles in the pyrolysis conducted using these metal oxide catalysts [83]. Ketonisation is a reaction in which two carboxylic acids are converted to ketones, carbon dioxide, and water, which can remarkably decrease the acidity of the pyrolysis-derived liquid products [84,85]. Ketonisation and aldol condensation also initiate the formation of aromatic hydrocarbons on the acid sites of ZSM-5 [86]. Although key reaction pathways have been outlined in several studies, further research should be conducted to obtain greater clarity regarding the reaction mechanisms at the molecular structure level. For example, the feedstock of interest can be simplified as model containing fatty acid compounds. More attention should also be paid to the online characterisation of intermediates during the catalytic pyrolysis of lipids. Molecular simulations can also be performed to comprehensively elucidate the reaction mechanisms with a focus on the location and types of oxygen-containing functional groups. 3.2 Catalysts for carbon chain modification Heterogeneous catalysts also enable carbon chain modification to convert lipids into alternative aviation fuels in the pyrolysis of non-edible lipids. The typical catalysts used for carbon chain modification are listed in Table 3. Because all types of zeolite catalysts can realise this aim, they have been extensively applied in the catalytic pyrolysis of heavy oil and biomass [87,88]. Zeolite catalysts are highly crystalline, porous, and exhibit excellent selectivity in terms of molecular size. They are predominantly used in modern industries owing to their high thermal stability, shape selectivity, adsorption capability, and controllable acidity. Their active sites (mainly acid sites) include Brønsted and Lewis acid centres that are generated via isomorphous substitution in zeolites [29]. Microporous, mesoporous, and hierarchical pore structures are present in all types of zeolite catalysts. The different pore distributions result in varying carbon-chain distributions in the liquid biofuels obtained via pyrolysis. Zeolites with micropores, mesopores, and hierarchical structures are introduced in this section, with a focus on unmodified zeolite catalysts; zeolites subjected to modifications, such as via metal oxide doping, are described as composite catalysts in Section 4. Micropore structures generally have numerous active sites that promote the deep cracking of feedstocks to produce gasoline with high yield. Zeolites, such as HZSM-5, ultra-stable Y zeolite, and beta zeolite, possess typical micropore structures. For example, ZSM-5 is a typical microporous zeolite catalyst suitable for gasoline production (carbon number of hydrocarbons < C8) [93–95]. The catalytic pyrolysis of rubber seed oil conducted using ultra-stable Y zeolite for at least six cycles yielded liquid fuels with a chemical composition similar to that of gasoline-based fuels (C8–C9 content >70%) [96]. This behaviour of microporous zeolite was mainly due to the numerous active acid sites, which led to significant carbon-chain cracking in the lipid or its key moiety. However, the pore size of the microporous zeolite limits the diffusion of large molecules inside its channels, resulting in thermal cracking of the large molecules in the lipid on the external surface of the catalyst or additional coke formation that blocks the porous catalyst channels. Therefore, with appropriate structural modifications or metal oxide doping, the catalytic activity, selectivity, and stability of zeolites can be improved or altered to produce alternative aviation fuels [97,98]. Microporous zeolites occasionally suffer from diffusion- and access-related limitations, which prolong the residence time of molecules on their surface and cause deactivation by accelerating undesired reactions (overcracking and coking). Zeolites, such as MCM-41and FSM-16, have a typical mesoporous structure that facilitates the transformation of lipids into liquid hydrocarbons with kerosene-based fuel streams at a higher selectivity than that of micropore zeolites [99]. For example, MCM-41 (mesoporous molecular sieves) exhibits a hexagonal array of unidimensional mesopores, and its diameter can be tuned in the range of 2–10 nm with a narrow pore size distribution [100]. Its surface area and average pore size varies from 550 to 1200 m2/g and from 1.8 to 2.8 nm, respectively. The selectivity of MCM-41 for the production of linear hydrocarbons increases and the yield of the liquid product decreases with an increase in its surface area [101]. The superiority of mesoporous zeolites is mostly attributed to the improved accessibility of acid sites and diffusion rate [102]. Therefore, mesoporous catalysts employed in bottom-up or top-down approaches are more selective to the production of middle-distillate bio-kerosene (C8–C16) and diesel (>C16) during lipid pyrolysis; however, they exhibit a lower reaction activity in the catalytic cracking of palm oil than that of microporous HZSM-5 zeolite [103]. Additionally, the introduction of mesopores into ZSM-5 boosts the yield of light olefins at the expense of aromatics because of the improved diffusion rate and reduced acidity [104]. Catalysts with hierarchical pore structures have also been developed because that tuning the micropore/mesopore ratio of catalysts can control the carbon chain distribution of liquid pyrolysis products. For example, a zeolite-Y/MCM-41 composite material (microphase zeolite Y as the core and mesophase MCM-41 as the shell) was conveniently synthesised by overgrowing MCM-41 on zeolite Y in an acidic medium containing a cationic surfactant and inorganic Si source [105]. This straightforward, low-cost synthesis method with wide operating conditions in acidic media has significant industrial potential. A palm oil conversion of 90–99 wt% was obtained using a composite of ZSM-5 coated with mesoporous aluminosilicate material. With an increase in mesophase ratio from 0.1 to 0.3, the percentage of kerosene fraction increased from 15% to 25%, and that of gasoline and diesel continuously decreased compared with that of the raw material ZSM-5 [106]. A hierarchical macro-meso-microporous structure was constructed using zeolite Y and kaolin as parent materials, which increased the accessibility of active sites in the composite to reactants, thereby resulting in a superior catalytic performance in cracking of heavy crude oil (>70% yield of gasoline and diesel). This was likely due to a decrease in the total acidity of the composite (0.571 mmol NH3/g-solid) compared to that of its parent material, zeolite Y (0.921 mmol NH3/g-solid) [107]. A multi-branched-product/single-branched-product ratio of greater than 0.3 for layered zeolite-containing silica–alumina catalysts resulted in a high selectivity for multi-branched compounds, even at high conversion [108]. Pd supported on hierarchical ZSM-5 zeolite achieved decarboxylation of fatty acids with over 90% selectivity to middle-distillate hydrocarbons (especially for C17) and conversions in the range of 60–85%. The main catalytic mechanism involved a combination of high accessibility and tailored acidity in the zeolite support, which favoured metal dispersion and interactions between Pd and the acid sites [109]. In particular, a single-step route using hierarchical zeolites has been developed for the production of alternative aviation fuels from lipids. The results indicated that the Ni-Wo catalyst supported on hierarchical zeolites yielded 40–50% kerosene-range hydrocarbons (C9–C15) with high isomerisation selectivity (isomer/n-alkane ratios of 3–13) [110]. Apart from improving the kerosene production, mesoporosity was noted to improve the performance of microporous zeolite in terms of conversion, gasoline yield, and light olefin yield by approximately 14%, 10%, and 30%, respectively [111]. Metal doping of the hierarchical zeolite supports could further improve these abilities. In addition to increases in activity and selectivity, the suppression of coke formation has also been observed [112,113]. These results indicate that large pores and distribution of acid sites can be tuned to efficiently convert lipids into kerosene-based fuels. However, the construction of these hierarchical structures requires more complicated operations and cost inputs. The distribution of micropores and mesopores in the catalysts can be carefully tuned to obtain liquid hydrocarbon fuels with a suitable carbon distribution. The improved molecular transport and reduced density of strong Brønsted acid sites are responsible for the superior catalytic performance of hierarchical catalysts in terms of selectivity and anti-coking abilities. The carbon chain modifications achieved using different porous zeolites are summarised in Fig. 5. Gasoline products are primarily obtained via the pyrolysis of lipids using microporous catalysts, whereas diesel products originate from the pyrolysis of lipids using mesoporous or non-porous catalysts, such as metal oxides, as mentioned in Section 3.1. Hierarchical catalysts, especially zeolites, have been developed using direct synthesis methods, recrystallisation of zeolites, and zeolitisation of mesoporous materials, which have been comprehensively summarised in several studies and excluded from this review [114,115]. 3.3 Catalysts for aromatisation Aromatic hydrocarbons are important components of liquid hydrocarbon fuels, which enhance thermal stability, heat value, and the performance of seals in airplanes via “swelling” [39,116]. Aromatic hydrocarbons in gasoline and diesel can be produced at contents exceeding 30% to achieve high-octane values; however, the aromatic hydrocarbon content in liquid biofuels should be limited because of ecological considerations. Moreover, combustion of the aromatic hydrocarbons in fuels can result in soot emissions and particulate matter in engines. A limitation on aromatic content (8–25%) has been established for alternative aviation fuels [38]. Therefore, in contrast to the maximum production of aromatic hydrocarbons in certain processes, the selectivity for aromatic hydrocarbons during the catalyst-assisted pyrolytic production of alternative aviation fuels using lipids should be controlled to satisfy national and industrial requirements and standards. Products from the conventional hydrotreatment of non-edible lipids mainly consist of C15–C18 alkanes without aromatic hydrocarbons; however, those from catalytic pyrolysis typically contain numerous aromatic hydrocarbons [38]. This is an important reason for the development of different processes for the pyrolytic production of alternative aviation fuels. The relative amounts of aromatic hydrocarbons in the liquid biofuels produced via catalytic pyrolysis strongly rely on the catalyst used and reaction conditions such as temperature, weight hourly space velocity, and acidity of the catalyst. Zeolites play a distinct role in the catalytic pyrolysis of lipids in terms of aromatisation. For example, catalytic pyrolysis of canola oil methyl ester in the presence of ZS50 (an HZSM-5 catalyst with a low Si/Al ratio) yielded 35% aromatic hydrocarbons relative to the amount of the methyl ester feedstock at a reaction temperature of 450 °C and space velocity of 2 h−1. Toluene was generated as the primary aromatic hydrocarbon, followed by p-meta xylenes and benzene [90]. Among zeolites, ZSM-5 is considered optimal for the production of aromatic hydrocarbons, especially monocyclic aromatics, primarily because of its Brønsted acidic sites and crystalline pore structure [26]. In a study conducted on the conversion of soybean oil into aviation fuels to achieve a high alkane selectivity and low aromatic hydrocarbon content, zeolite HY exhibited higher aviation-range alkane selectivity (40.3%) and lower jet-range aromatic hydrocarbon selectivity (23.8%) than those of zeolite HZSM-5 (13.8% and 58.9%, respectively) [117]. Additionally, the microwave-assisted pyrolysis of Chinese tallow kernel oil with a silicon-carbide (SiC)-foamed ceramic catalyst achieved a maximum aromatic content of 89.7 wt%, indicating its suitability for aromatic production of fine chemicals rather than that of liquid biofuel components [16]. Similar to the carbon chain modification of lipids by zeolites, the active sites in zeolites used for aromatisation are also Brønsted and Lewis acid sites. In most cases, the aromatisation role of catalysts, particularly zeolites, should be suppressed during the production of alternative aviation fuels [118]. For example, the Brønsted acidity and aromatic content of La–Fe-modified Si-MCM-41 decreased from 22.49 to 5.86 μmol/g and from 37.51 wt% to 14.52 wt%, respectively, compared with those of the parent catalyst, Si-MCM-41 [118]. This indicates that the Brønsted acid centres are the major active sites for aromatisation reactions [119]. Additionally, alkali treatment results in enlarged ZSM-5 pores and inhibited catalyst deactivation with a slight reduction in the aromatic content in the products [26]. The catalytic pyrolysis mechanism of zeolites in terms of aromatisation is shown in Fig. 6. Aromatic hydrocarbons are formed during the catalytic pyrolysis of lipids primarily because of the cyclisation, Diels–Alder addition, and dehydrogenation reactions. Aromatisation during the catalytic pyrolysis of lipids is also linked to an increase in coke formation. Although microporous zeolite has noteworthy abilities for carbon chain cracking and aromatisation, the aromatic hydrocarbon yield is considerably high and exceeds the limit established for aviation fuels (8–25%). Therefore, microporous zeolites are suitable for the production of aromatic compounds from the perspective of fine chemicals but inappropriate for the production of alternative aviation fuels. In most situations, aromatisation of lipids by zeolites should be suppressed by increasing the number of mesoporous structures. 3.4 Other catalysts and their functions Apart from the catalysts mentioned in Sections 3.1–3.3, certain additional catalysts have also been applied in catalytic pyrolysis, such as silica–alumina, basic catalysts, molten salts, carbides, and nitrides. Conventional silica–alumina and basic catalysts were applied in catalytic cracking during the early stages of research on catalytic pyrolysis [21,121], as shown in Table 4. The acidity of liquid biofuels is closely related to their oxygen content, and a decrease in the oxygen content can reduce the acidity of liquid biofuels, which can be accomplished by basic catalysts [122]. Na2CO3 is a typical basic catalyst that reacts with primary pyrolysis products (fatty acids) to form fatty acid salts, which subsequently transform into hydrocarbons by secondary cracking of carboxyl groups. These reactions can decrease the acid value of the produced liquid hydrocarbon biofuels. Several pilot-scale studies have been conducted to leverage the low cost and simple operation of these catalysts [123,124]. For example, diesel-like fuels were produced via catalytic pyrolysis of crude palm oil using 20 wt% Na2CO3 catalyst at 450 °C and atmospheric pressure. This process yielded 65.86 wt% organic liquid products, whose distillation resulted in a diesel fraction composed of hydrocarbons (91.38 wt%) and oxygenated compounds (8.62 wt%) [123]. After mechanical mixing with CaO catalyst, the acid value of biofuel produced from soybean oil decreased from 85.21 to ~20 mg-KOH/g during the catalytic pyrolysis with the composite catalyst, La–Fe-modified Si-MSM-41 [118]. All these catalysts can decrease the acidity of catalytic pyrolysis products via acid–base, deoxygenation, or synergistic reactions. However, single-component basic catalysts have inferior comprehensive catalytic abilities, such as aromatisation and carbon chain cracking. Silica–alumina catalysts with different Si/Al ratios were typically used in the early research on cracking; these have medium-to-strong acidities and have recently been substituted by zeolites in catalytic pyrolysis [121]. High-alumina-content (>30 wt%) silica–alumina materials are typically used as cracking catalysts to achieve maximum catalytic activity. For example, a γ-Al2O3 catalyst was used for catalytic pyrolysis of microalgae-derived oily extracts, and the results indicated that the hydrocarbon concentration varied from 46% to 92%, and the C9–C15 fraction in the hydrocarbons was the main component of a precursor for bio-kerosene or drop-in fuels [125]. Nanosized γ-Al2O3 (3–6 nm) has also been used to produce several grades of biofuels via catalytic cracking of non-edible vegetable oils. The obtained biofuels were within ASTM specification limits in terms of properties such as viscosity, kinematic viscosity, pour point, cloud point, and acid value [30]. Silica–alumina catalysts exhibited decent selectivity in the rapid catalytic pyrolysis of durian rind in a drop-type two-stage reactor, and yielded bio-oil with hydrocarbons, furan derivatives, and aromatic compounds as the major components at 400–600 °C [126]. The Brønsted acidity and catalytic activity of silica–alumina catalysts are lower than those of zeolites, in addition to their coking tendency. However, in most cases, silica–alumina materials are used as supports for composite catalysts rather than on their own, as reviewed in Section 4. 4 Multi-functional composite catalysts for production of alternative aviation fuels Although conventional zeolites show tremendous potential as catalysts for the production of alternative aviation fuels via lipid cracking, composite catalysts are required to simultaneously realise complex functions such as heteroatom removal, carbon chain modification, and aromatisation [130]. To satisfy these requirements or functions, composite catalysts are synthesised primarily via metal oxide doping and the use of supports with hierarchical pore structures. Generally, zeolites, molecular sieves, silica–alumina, and carbonaceous materials can provide high surface areas and pore volumes for the active phases of metal oxide dopants. Ensuring high selectivity of the composite catalysts is key to the production of alternative aviation fuels via lipid pyrolysis; this requires the presence of both mesoporous and microporous systems in the catalyst. Mesoporous systems can improve the accessibility of active sites, and micropore systems are important for shape-selective catalysis, providing high activity and selectivity. Common composite catalysts and their performance are listed in Table 5. The main synthesis strategy involves anchoring metal oxides onto various supports, including silica–alumina, porous carbon materials, and zeolites, which are successively introduced in this section. Silica–alumina-supported metal oxides are typical composite catalysts in which the metal oxide enables deoxygenation, and the silica–alumina support ensures a high dispersion of the active metal oxide. For example, hydrocarbon mixtures produced via pyrolysis using alumina catalysts doped with tin and zinc oxides show a significant reduction (30%) in oxygenated compounds compared with that of hydrocarbon mixtures obtained via catalyst-free thermal cracking [136]. The Ni/MgO-Al2O3 catalyst exhibited the highest reported conversion (>60%) for feedstock (oleic acid) and high selectivity (>10%) to C17 compounds at a reaction temperature of 350 °C in the catalytic decarboxylation of oleic acid, indicating that free Ni species in the catalytic system facilitated oleic acid decarboxylation. [137]. The presence of active metals in mesoporous SiO2–Al2O3-supported Co–Ca catalysts led to high deoxygenation activity exclusively via decarboxylation and decarbonylation pathways, with a maximum n-(C8–C20) hydrocarbon yield of 73% and high selectivity to n-C15 and n-C17 fractions, indicating that the acid–base active sites of these catalysts enabled selective decarboxylation and decarbonylation of triglycerides [55]. Additionally, the bifunctional NiO-CaO/SiO2-Al2O3 catalyst achieved a hydrocarbon fraction of 92%, a diesel-like fuel composition [n-(C130–C20)] of the produced liquid fuels, and high selectivity to C15 and C17 [138]. In conclusion, the produced liquid hydrocarbons are typically not in the range of kerosene (C8–C16) owing to the weak cracking performance of the silica–alumina supports. The use of metal oxides supported on porous carbon materials (such as activated carbon, carbon nanotubes, and microporous carbon) is another synthetic strategy for composite catalysts. For example, 5 wt% Pt supported on activated carbon (5 wt% Pt/C) was determined to be optimal for microalgae pyrolysis after catalytic deoxygenation, as it reduced the oxygen content (<2%) in the resulting bio-oil. Pentadecane was the major component in the liquid fuels, although short-chain paraffins produced by cracking were also found in the liquid products [139]. Catalytic deoxygenation of waste cooking oil also led to a high deoxygenation reactivity with a straight-chain C8–C20 hydrocarbon yield of 72% using a bimetallic acid–base nanosized catalyst (CaO-La2O3/AC) in a hydrogen-free environment, which consistently formed major n-C15 fractions at contents of > 80%. This composite catalyst favoured the decarboxylation/decarbonylation route over cracking [131]. The Ag2O3-La2O3/ACnano catalyst was effective in the catalytic conversion of waste cooking oil to green diesel for six continuous runs, achieving a constant hydrocarbon yield (>80%) and high selectivity (>93%) to n-C15 and n-C17 under mild reaction conditions (350 °C and 120 min). The weak acidic sites and the considerable acidic and basic strength of the catalyst were primarily responsible for its performance [17]. However, similar to the silica–alumina-supported metal oxides, the liquid hydrocarbons produced using carbon-supported metal oxides are predominantly in the diesel range [140], owing to the low number of active sites in the activated carbon supports. These pyrolysis products must be subjected to additional cracking to yield alternative aviation fuels in the kerosene range. Numerous studies have been conducted on supporting active components on microporous, mesoporous, and hierarchical zeolites to modify or promote deoxygenation, aromatisation, and carbon chain cracking in triglyceride pyrolysis. The main active components of the incorporated metal oxides, such as Ga, Al, Cu, Ni, Zn, Sn, Mg, and Ti, can improve the deoxygenation ability of zeolite catalysts. For example, impregnation of hierarchical zeolites with different metals (Sn, Cu, Ni, or Mg) enhances the extent of deoxygenation [32,141]. For example, Mg-loaded hierarchical zeolites achieved a deoxygenation efficiency of 42.6% compared with that (23.4%) of the parent catalyst, ZSM-5. Moreover, the Lewis acid sites were found to be linked to decarbonylation and decarboxylation reactions, whereas Brønsted acid sites were associated with the formation of aromatics [141]. Additionally, the anti-coking ability of HZSM-5 has been enhanced by phosphorus doping during the upgrading of the pyrolytic vapours. Moreover, Zn loading promotes carbenium-ion formation and hydrogen transfer, which improves the aromatisation performance of HZSM-5 [142]. A SBA-15-based bi-functional catalyst, SBA-15 @MgO@Zn, was synthesised to improve the deoxygenation of waste cooking oils to yield hydrocarbon-rich biofuels. This composite catalyst not only avoids the shortcomings of acidic catalysts that readily produce coke but also of basic catalysts that induce saponification [143]. Rare-earth oxides, such as CeO2, have also been employed to modify zeolites, and have received extensive research attention as active components. CeO2 effectively regulates the acidic properties of zeolites with an increase and decrease in the number of Lewis and Brønsted acid sites, respectively, resulting in high selectivity (84.0%) to light aromatics, low coke formation (2.42 wt%), and high carbon yield (90%) of light aromatics after seven regenerations [144]. The catalytic performance of composite catalysts is not only linked to their composition and structure but also to reaction conditions such as temperature, pressure, and liquid hourly space velocity (catalyst loading). Different reaction conditions are typically adopted for various reactors, with fixed-bed, slurry, and fluidised-bed reactors being the main industrial reactors performing the catalytic reactions [145–147]. The fixed-bed reactor has a simple and straightforward construction, but is disadvantageous in terms of coke deposition, which causes blockages and increases the pressure drop. The fluidised-bed reactor has high heat and mass transfer and solid mixing regimes; however, it has a complex design and operation, especially for circulating fluidised beds. The slurry-bed reactor with mechanical stirring has a high heat capacity, which enables adequate temperature control and straightforward replacement of deactivated catalysts [148]. Recently, a one-pot reaction model using composite catalysts was found to be effective in enabling coupling of multiple functions such as deoxygenation, carbon chain cracking, and aromatisation, along with reducing the fixed investment and operating costs [23,149]; this model simplifies sequential or multistep reactions and is beneficial for the economics of the catalytic process. In summary, numerous studies have been conducted on composite catalysts of zeolite-supported metal oxides because of their comprehensive catalytic performance in aspects such as deoxygenation, carbon chain cracking, and aromatisation [134,150]; this is possibly the most suitable catalyst synthesis strategy for alternative aviation fuel production. A synthetic strategy for composite catalysts (i.e. hierarchical-zeolite-supported metal oxides) suitable for alternative aviation fuel production via lipid pyrolysis can be proposed ( Fig. 7). The active components (metal oxides) and supports (microporous and mesoporous zeolites) play different roles in the transformation of the molecular structures of lipids during the catalytic pyrolysis. The active components (metal oxides) are used to remove heteroatoms, whereas supports (hierarchical zeolites) are used for carbon chain cracking and aromatisation. Enhancements in the surface chemistry and interactions between active components and supports lead to improvements in catalytic efficiency [151–154], which should be thoroughly investigated in the future with respect to the catalytic pyrolysis of lipids. The active sites in composite catalysts are a combination of metal oxides and zeolites, which are mainly Brønsted and Lewis acid centres generated by the active components, supports, and their synergetic effects [155,156]. Additionally, drop-in alternative aviation fuels can be produced using these composite catalysts in a single step. 5 Deactivation of catalysts during lipid pyrolysis and its prevention Non-edible lipids are an alternative source of liquid biofuels, and their molecular structure can be transformed via catalytic pyrolysis. Composite catalysts (zeolite-supported metal oxides) are typical cracking catalysts that remove oxygen from the active sites in metal oxides and crack the long carbon chains of the lipids into gasoline, kerosene, and diesel. However, the reaction activity, thermal stability, and product selectivity of these composite catalysts are hindered by certain detrimental effects such as metal poisoning, carbon deposition, and presence of heteroatoms in the lipids. Catalyst deactivation is mainly induced by thermal and hydrothermal deactivation, metal poisoning, carbon deposition/coking, and heteroatom poisoning (S and N). The main reason for catalyst deactivation in lipid pyrolysis is coking, which occurs on the surface or inner pores of the catalysts [157,158]. In this section, the reasons for the deactivation of the composite catalysts are described, along with certain anti-deactivation strategies. Coking-induced catalyst deactivation is a more severe issue in the pyrolysis of non-edible lipids than sintering and poisoning. The coke deposit on catalysts blocks their different parts (external or internal porous structures) owing to differences in the feedstock and process parameters. The coking-induced deactivation occurs as a complex reaction involving several physical and chemical interactions. Different types of coking have been explored for numerous types of catalysts and processes [159–161]. For example, microporous catalysts (such as HZSM-5) exhibit a higher coking rate in the catalytic pyrolysis of palm oil, whereas composites (CZA35 and CMA25) show improved anti-deactivation performance [162]. Transition-metal-based modification of zeolites can also prevent coking on the surface of catalysts by reducing the number of active sites on the zeolite supports [14]. Several strategies have been explored to mitigate coking, such as alkali treatment, dealumination, and the use of nanosized microporous crystals. Alkali treatment generates secondary mesopores in ZSM-5 and inhibits deactivation, with a slight loss of reaction activity [26]. Moreover, alkali treatment has been used primarily to construct hierarchical structures of the catalysts, which increases accessibility to bulky molecules, intermediates, and cracking products [163], and achieves high selectivity to C5–C11 liquid products [164]. Nanoscale catalytic materials can enhance selectivity and stability, as well as exhibit high anti-coking ability through short diffusion pathways [165,166]. Although an increased H/Ceffective ratio in biomass feedstock or high hydrogen pressure in the reaction environment can reduce coking to avoid catalyst deactivation [167], this strategy deviates from the scope of this review, which is limited to hydrogen-free catalytic pyrolysis. In conclusion, the use of hierarchical structures is an effective coking-reduction strategy, and the coking mechanism should be explored in future research on the catalytic pyrolysis of non-edible lipids. Thermal deactivation, which is mainly referred to as sintering, generally occurs at high temperatures during the catalyst regeneration stage and is accelerated by the presence of water vapour. At high reaction temperatures, small particles migrate to larger particles or agglomerate directly to form larger particles, which reduces the number of active sites in the catalyst and results in catalyst deactivation. For instance, metal particle sintering and alloying of Ni with Cu were observed in a supported Ni-Cu/Al2O3 catalyst used in the deoxygenation of waste lipids [168]. During the vapour-phase carbonylation of ethanol to propionic acid, the addition of CeO2 improves the dispersion of Ni on the supports and suppresses the sintering of Ni crystallites [169]. The thermal deactivation mechanism is also important for catalytic pyrolysis. Atomic trajectory tracing has indicated that the surface diffusion of metals is highly localised, which differs from the conventional understanding of freely moving high-mobility surface atoms [170]. In fact, the slow thermal deactivation of catalysts during pyrolysis can also be easily prevented using optimised operating parameters or computational modelling [170]. Most sintering occurs during the combustion of the deposits on catalyst surfaces, because most catalytic pyrolysis reactions are performed with continuous regeneration (removal of deposits by combustion), such as in a fluid catalytic cracking (FCC) unit. However, particular attention should be paid to the reaction temperature used for catalytic pyrolysis or control of the regeneration process to avoid deactivation by thermal degradation. Poisoning refers to a strong chemical reaction between the active sites of catalysts and poisonous species in the feedstock (such as heavy metals and nitrogen-containing compounds). These poisonous species block the active sites, including metals and basic compounds sourced from the feedstock and pyrolysis products. Poisoning predominantly occurs via metals in feedstocks such as Ni, V, As, Hg, Fe, and Cu. For instance, poisoning by metals in feedstocks can be assessed by chemical and phase-sensitive X-ray microscopy, which enables a comprehensive understanding of deactivation in real-life catalysis and the design of novel composite catalysts [171]. During the catalytic gasification/reforming of waste tires, the deactivation of nickel catalysts by sulfur and carbon was monitored by transmission electron microscopy with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy [172]. To prevent catalyst poisoning, pre-treatment and process parameter optimisation must be conducted prior to the catalytic cracking of lipids [173]. Apart from the metal-related poisoning of catalysts, deactivation can also occur owing to the unwanted reactivity of solid acid–base catalysts for the poisonous species (such S- and N-containing compounds) present in the feedstock or intermediates of the catalytic pyrolysis reaction. For example, numerous basic products (such as ammonia and cyanide) are produced during the primary thermal cracking of microalgal lipids, which subsequently react with the acidic active sites of the catalysts, resulting in their rapid deactivation. The presence of H2O, CO2, and SO2 in the catalytic removal of toluene over supported Pt nano- and single-atom-catalysts decreases the catalytic activity and stability [174]. Additionally, catalyst deactivation is caused by the presence of highly unsaturated bonds in algal lipids, which act as poisons by adsorbing strongly to the catalyst surface or forming coke precursors [175]. Phenols sourced from primary thermal cracking are important intermediates that result in zeolite deactivation via coke formation and chemical absorption on active sites [176]. It is worth noting that the deactivation caused by these poisonous species is generally reversible by regeneration, whereas metal poisoning is irreversible. In summary, catalyst coking is a crucial factor enabling deactivation during the catalytic pyrolysis of lipids, which requires high-frequency regeneration (mainly via combustion) to recover the catalytic activity. During the regeneration of catalysts, considerable attention should be paid to temperature control to mitigate the sintering of the catalysts. Additionally, sub-nanometric metal clusters in zeolites have been encapsulated in recent studies to enhance the anti-sintering effect and protect the active sites [19,177]. Optimising the strong metal–support interaction (SMSI) is another strategy for imparting anti-coking and anti-sintering abilities to composite catalysts because of the steric restrictions and electronic effects at the atomic level for catalysts and supports [178,179]. For example, tungsten-carbide-based materials with Ni exhibit excellent catalytic performance in the pyrolysis of jatropha oil, resulting in a deoxygenation efficiency and C15–18 selectivity of 99.7% and 94.5%, respectively. Moreover, the synergistic effect between the Ni and W2C support plays an important role in their catalytic performance [180]. 6 Pyrolytic production of alternative aviation fuels using microalgal lipids Microalgae have attracted increasing attention in recent years as third-generation biofuels. The main advantages of microalgae are their rapid growth [20–60 g/(m2·d)], high lipid content, and lack of competition with conventional agricultural production in terms of arable land and water [42,181]. Microalgae have a higher photosynthetic efficiency (3–8%) than that of conventional land plants (~10–15 times higher), along with a high oil (lipid) productivity (58,700 L/ha). In particular, a high lipid content can be obtained from the microalgae (36 wt% on dry biomass) under N-depleted cultivation conditions [182]. Only 2.5% of the existing agricultural land in the USA is required to satisfy its national energy consumption. In China, 0.3 million hm2 of marginal land exists (only usable land is considered), which highlights the remarkable potential for large-scale microalgae cultivation and productivity. However, the high cultivation cost of microalgae due to harvesting and drying hinders their large-scale industrial applications. Lipids are important components of microalgae (up to 30 wt%) [9], and the main carbon-number distribution in microalgal lipids is C14–C22 for a single fatty-acid chain [183,184]. These can be used to produce liquid fuels such as gasoline, diesel, and kerosene to replace their fossil-fuel-derived counterparts. Alternative aviation fuels have attracted considerable attention because the aviation industry currently discharges ~2% of the global CO2 emissions, which is accelerating with the rapid societal developments [184]. Pyrolysis enables cracking of the O-containing functional groups in lipid molecules and long carbon chains (saturated and unsaturated) [185–188], which is a promising lipid-to-liquid-biofuel conversion pathway. However, thermal cracking of lipids cannot completely remove heteroatoms (O and N) [189]. Catalytic pyrolysis has recently been applied to microalgal lipid refineries using catalysts such as bases (NaOH and Na2CO3), bentonite clay, zeolites, molecular sieves, metal oxides, and their combinations by physical or chemical means [190–192]. However, these catalysts are rarely used in the pyrolysis of microalgal lipids for alternative-liquid-biofuel production, particularly for alternative aviation fuels. Based on Sections 3 and 4, the proposed synthetic strategy of composite catalysts, that is, doping metal oxides (or other active components) into hierarchical-pore zeolites, can be adopted in the catalytic pyrolysis of microalgal lipids. This route can theoretically produce alternative aviation fuels in line with ASTM 7566 ( Fig. 8), and should be targeted more in future research on catalysts and alternative aviation fuel production. 7 Conclusion and future suggestions The catalytic pyrolysis of non-edible lipids for the production of alternative aviation fuels was discussed in this article, with a focus on various catalysts, their performance, and synthetic strategies. The catalysts employed for alternative aviation fuel production primarily achieve heteroatom removal, carbon chain modification, and aromatisation. Metal oxide catalysts can efficiently reduce the oxygen content through decarbonylation and decarboxylation pathways, whereas microporous/mesoporous zeolites can promote the cracking of fatty acid carbon chains to yield gasoline-, kerosene-, and diesel-range fuels. Zeolites also permit aromatisation to produce aromatic hydrocarbons, which helps ensure an aromatic hydrocarbon content of 8–25% in the resulting aviation fuels. Composite catalysts (metal oxides supported on hierarchical porous zeolites) have been proposed for one-step production of alternative aviation fuels to reduce the number of reactors. The metal oxide and zeolite components of composite catalysts realise deoxygenation and aromatisation, respectively. High selectivity for kerosene (C8–C16) can be realised by modifying the ratio of microporous and mesoporous structures in zeolites. This paper is anticipated to facilitate the engineering design of novel catalyst systems for the efficient cracking of lipids to yield renewable hydrocarbon fuels, especially alternative aviation fuels. This review indicates that catalytic pyrolysis is a noteworthy technique for the production of alternative aviation fuels from non-edible lipids. However, further research should be conducted on synthesising more effective catalysts and optimising the reaction conditions to improve the selectivity for alternative aviation fuels and the anti-deactivation ability of catalysts. To enable the development of novel composite catalysts and pathways for cost-effective pyrolytic production of alternative aviation fuels, the following suggestions are provided to facilitate future research, with a focus on the large-scale and low-cost production of microalgae, engineering of active sites in catalysts, deactivation mechanism of catalysts, improvement of economics, and certification of the pathways for pyrolytic production of alternative aviation fuels: (1) Microalgae are a promising energy source, as they do not compete with conventional agricultural production for arable land and water. They also have higher photosynthetic efficiency than that of traditional land plants. However, their commercial application in biofuel production is hindered by high cultivation and harvesting costs. Further decreases in the cultivation cost of microalgae can be achieved by determining optimal growth conditions and enabling genetic modification of microalgae species for their large-scale and low-cost production. Moreover, the efficiency of lipid extraction from microalgae should be increased to facilitate their utilisation in the catalytic pyrolysis for alternative-aviation-fuel production. (2) The production of alternative aviation fuels and the development of multifunctional catalysts depend on the engineering of the active sites of composite catalysts (zeolite-supported metal oxides). Therefore, the distribution and reaction mechanisms of unsaturated coordination, defect, Brønsted acid, and Lewis acid sites in composite catalysts must be elucidated. Additionally, the SMSI between metal oxides and zeolites should be examined to enhance the performance of these composite catalysts. (3) Catalyst deactivation is a major challenge in catalytic lipid pyrolysis. Although coking, which is the main deactivation pathway, has been sufficiently examined, the coking mechanism in novel composite catalysts used in the transformation of lipids into alternative aviation fuels should be explored. Additionally, the poisoning and sintering mechanisms of these composite catalysts require further attention. For example, the poisoning due to the high N and O contents in microalgal lipids and related functional groups should be investigated. (4) Economic performance remains a challenge for pyrolytic production of alternative aviation fuels compared to petroleum-based and lipid-hydrotreatment-derived aviation fuels. The economic performance of alternative aviation fuels derived from lipid feedstocks should be improved by investigating different lipid sources, along with performing process integration and multi-parameter optimisation for the catalytic pyrolysis. Additionally, research and development of industrial reactors should be targeted to optimise the economic performance of pathways for pyrolysis-based production of alternative aviation fuels, although several industrial reactors, such as the FCC, have been developed. (5) Certification of pyrolytic production pathways for alternative aviation fuels by governments and stakeholders is also essential because large-scale applications in airplanes and engines require strict approval, such as adherence to ASTM D4054 (Standard Practice for Qualification and Approval of New Aviation Turbine Fuels and Fuel Additives). More attention should be paid to this aspect to accelerate the applications of alternative aviation fuels derived from catalytic pyrolysis. coredata.dc:description: Non-edible lipids are an alternative source of liquid hydrocarbon fuels, particularly aviation fuels. As a transformation pathway, the catalytic pyrolysis of lipids can remove oxygen atoms and modify molecular structures via carbon chain cracking and aromatisation. However, this pathway has not yet been certified for the production of alternative aviation fuels. Therefore, a detailed review of various heterogeneous catalysts for the conversion of lipids into hydrocarbon fuels with molecular weights and structures suitable for use in aviation is presented herein, with a focus on aspects such as their physical and chemical properties, pore distributions and structures, active sites, key functions, catalytic performance, and pyrolysis mechanisms. Metal oxides can effectively remove oxygen atoms, whereas zeolites can achieve long-carbon-chain cracking to yield desirable gasoline-, kerosene-, or diesel-range fuels. Moreover, zeolites typically permit aromatisation, which yields the aromatic hydrocarbons required for liquid fuels. Modification of the pore structures of zeolites to yield hierarchical pores can improve the production of C8–C16-range liquid fuels to maximise the bio-kerosene yield. Therefore, composite catalysts (metal oxides supported on zeolites with hierarchical pores) can be effective for molecular-level structural modification in the pyrolytic production of alternative aviation fuels using lipids. However, rapid deactivation due to coking, poisoning, and sintering hinder the operation of these catalysts. Coking, which is predominantly responsible for pyrolysis catalyst deactivation, should be targeted in future research on novel catalysts. The synthetic strategy of catalysts and the mitigation of their issues are critical to the design of novel catalytic pyrolysis systems for the efficient cracking of triglyceride-rich feedstock to yield alternative aviation fuels.
coredata.dc:title: Synthetic strategies and performance of catalysts for pyrolytic production of alternative aviation fuels using non-edible lipids: A critical review
